segments.text: the day they were supposed to make the reactor, or trial reactor, go critical under the stands in Chicago, as a member of that team, while he came on to work in his normal time.
But in his briefcase, they brought along a bottle of wine.
So when they
controls were withdrawn and the chain reaction in fact occurred.
And it was shut down and everybody was elated of course because they had achieved a chain reaction, the first in the history of the world.
Gene reached in his briefcase and he got the bottle of wine and he says, I think this warrants a celebration.
So he passed the wine around and had a taste of wine there in the reactor under the stands in Chicago that day.
Gene is a really wonderful person.
I was wondering about your thoughts when
Senator McCarthy again, went against Oppenheimer, maligned him.
Well, that's a hard one.
First, it hurts my pride to see
whom I considered a knothead like McCarthy, able to call some man like Oppenheimer to task.
That seems an injustice to me that I don't stomach very well.
And of course I felt the same way with
McCarthy's trial of Stevens, who was Secretary of the Army at that time.
And Oppenheimer, as I said, left himself open for something like that.
And of course McCarthy was going to take advantage of it, because that's what he was trying to prove.
But I don't think that's the forum for it.
I think it was the forum for it.
I don't think it's the best interest of the nation for him to do it, and I don't think McCarthy is qualified to do it, even if Oppenheimer was guilty of it, which he may have been, as far as I know.
Did the Air Force see Oppenheimer as a threat because he was against development of the H-bomb?
No, not really, because Oppenheimer was not a pinnacle of his own on that.
When the Air Force looked at that,
more in the sense that these people had created something that they didn't know what to do with, and they wanted to keep the closet door closed just as long as they could do it.
We said to ourselves, we can understand that desire, but we think it's unrealistic.
And we think that the security interests of the United States dictate that we get busy.
And we have to do it if we can convince the right people, even though the Oppenheimers and others don't agree.
And we went on that basis.
Was there friction when you worked for Oppenheimer because the Air Force took a different view than he did?
No.
Did he ever, did he ever sort of chide you or say anything cynical to you about the Air Force?
No.
Because he knew that your stand or his, the Air Force stand was different from his.
Oh yes, he knew the Air Force stand was different from his and he knew mine individually was.
as of the time the decision was made, Mr. Webster's position, who was my boss, was contrary to his.
But no, he was never there.
He didn't seem to let those things bother him at all.
The fact that I was opposite to him on that
And as soon as the President said, we're going to go ahead, well, he forgot about it.
He got busy going ahead.
Now, I can't be critical of anything he did after that insofar as keeping us from getting there.
He went on and contributed his best knowledge, I think, to us.
So I can't say that he held out.
They did just a different tribute.

I sometimes feel that most of those guys felt like they had to take that position, and they hoped the president would overrule them, and their conscience would be clear, and everything would be all right.
Really, I don't say that specifically about Oppenheimer, but I mean,
I think a number of them felt that way.
And I think that's the reason they took the position.
They had a pretty good idea Truman was gonna ride over it anyhow.
He had decided to drop it, which was the hardest thing.
Yeah, drop the bomb, exactly.
Now let's get back to your job as air planner.
And you said that the impact of the atomic bomb was one of the more significant aspects and was very significant and changed war plans.
In what way?
What I really meant was the advent of the atomic bomb changed one of the things that
changed every war plan that you try to make, because you have to take account of something that had not existed before.
Take account of it in terms of what you could do with it if you had it.
And of course, we were planning to have it, because we were building it.
And the effect on other forces that didn't have it.
But in the U.S. Armed Forces, no one at the start had the capability to use it, except the Air Force and the form that it was in.
We knew that was not a good form to have it in, so everybody wanted to get in a position to use it.
That's the scramble for
nuclear torpedoes, nuclear guns, nuclear propelled airplanes, nuclear V1s, V2s, all kinds of applications.
Delivery systems.
And we pursued all of those.
Now, of course, the period from Potsdam in July of August 1945

down to the Fulton speech, the so-called Iron Curtain speech of Winston Churchill, which was in March of 1946, just a month or so after you assumed your position, was a period in which American foreign policy was changing rapidly toward the Soviet Union.
We were becoming very disillusioned with what the Soviets were doing in Eastern Europe.
And then a year after that, in March of 1947, we get the Truman Doctrine,
I would think that sometime in 1946 the United States starts to develop plans to bomb the Soviet Union.
Do you remember when that was?
Well, war plans except for
contingencies like scrambles in the Middle East, things like that, all involved the Soviet Union because it was the only potential adversary that there was.
And so we as air planters began to
to use them in our plans just as fast as they were available.
Probably a little faster, as a matter of fact, because not all of us knew how many was available or when.
How many bombs were available.
Yes.
Of course, that's all you had.
There wasn't a question of it.
What about as far as Soviet targets?
What were the major targets back then?
I wonder if those have changed over the years.
Well, Soviet targets have changed, of course, almost directly as the numbers increase, because you can achieve, have a lot more flexibility and achieve an objective by doing that.
To say that there was a target list in which things were
targeted that early would be an error.
They won.
When did we get a list like that, do you think?
Well, I can't answer specifically, but it was after we had a significant number of missiles capable of reaching it, which was a good many years later than this.
Sure, absolutely.
I was well out of the planning business long before that happened.
Although of course we were, we were planning targets even then, but not targeting is when there is a difference.
It takes years and years to build the information necessary to do a target system.
you gotta know what's there and that isn't so easy.
Right, absolutely.
And the nature of it and whether you can, what it takes to destroy it.
And were you involved with those targets within Russia?
Picking out which targets should be hit in case of a war or how many, well at that time all we had was B-29s, how many B-29s should go?
Oh yes, all of these things have to be included in every war plan.
The answer is yes.
Okay.
There was another thing that I was interested in, and that was increasing American
British relations after the war.

I've done some research in this and it appeared that right after the war, in the fall of 1945, Americans were not so concerned with continuing the joint relationship that we had in Europe, especially with the British, which was so very close.
We weren't so concerned until 1946 when we realized that the Soviet Union was our new number one enemy, and relations improved rapidly.
Did you find that relations improved as far as the Royal Air Force and the American Air Force throughout 1946?
Yes, it improved between the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the British Chiefs of Staff, which is where I was.
The planning groups of the two entities met, I know I don't start to say regularly, that isn't quite right, but quite often.
Every week or so?
No, every month or so.
And would pursue various aspects of joint
And toward the Soviet Union for the most part.
Yes.
Oh, yes.
Essentially all of it.
But it's more examining what are the capabilities to do this or what are the capabilities to do that.
I'm sure individually we integrated those into our own plans back here.
But we didn't sit down with the British and make a joint, or combined it would be in this case, plan for any kind of offensive action against the Soviet Union.
But was it understood that in case of some sort of crisis then it would be a joint action?
Well, yes, and there were a lot of joint things going on.
We still had forces in England, air forces.
Actually, I guess still have.
We did for a monument many years after that.
And so there was concerted plans for employment of those forces.
And if you employ a party of forces, while the others have sure got to be in that stint.
Now did the British have an office right in the Pentagon?
I don't know about the Pentagon.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff at that time were over where the State Department headquarters is now, and there were two British missions here in Washington.
I'm not sure if they were in either of those buildings, but
They were in the British Embassy and in buildings leased by the British Embassy.
So they were always close at hand.
Yes, they were in Washington, although to my memory they were not in that building.
I don't remember their being there.
Now in August, September of 1946, Field Marshal Montgomery
visited Washington, D.C. and he had been in Canada talking to their military men and then he came down to Washington and talked to Admiral Leahy and some of our Joint Chiefs of Staff.
As a matter of fact, they all took a trip down to the Potomac and it was supposed to be a social occasion, but they all talked about joint forces.
Did you remember when he came?
Were you at all involved?
I remember when he came but I wasn't involved at all and I didn't see him.
I didn't prepare any positions for anybody for that meeting and so I
it's just a point in history for me, I just don't know.
Okay.
Of course another thing was increased defense relations with the Canadians, which eventually led to the establishment of the Dew Line.
Yes, and the North American Air Defense Command.
Yeah.
Did you have any dealings with that?
Well, no, not really.
We had a
The concept of the due line and all was prepared primarily by the Joint Strategic Survey Committee of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
At the time we were working with them and we worked on various pieces of that total.
But they carried the ball and so we didn't have too much to do with it.
And after it was once accepted,
Well then even the Joint Staff didn't have much to do with it.
It was taken care of by the Air Force and carried out.
I was in Washington for nearly 20 years and I was not in the Air Force any of that 20 years.
I was in the Joint Staff or something having to do with the atomic energy business or answering to the Secretary of Defense all those years in there.
Air Force representative, but never was in the Air Force.
Even my last job as commander of the Joint Task Force 7, I was responsible to the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the one hand, and to the commissioners of the Atomic Energy Commission on the other.
So still wasn't in the Air Force.
During 1946 and 1947, one of the major battlefronts was Greece, and of course the Civil War in Greece, and that led to the rise of the Truman Doctrine.
I was wondering if you as air planner had anything to do with
helping the Greeks, helping the government there, giving them air supplies, helping them in any way train men.
I know they did send some Greeks over here to become pilots.
They did.
And so far as the Joint Staff was concerned, that again was a Joint Strategic Survey paper.
And then they
The actions were carried out by the executive agent, which I guess would have been Navy in that case.
And I didn't have anything to do with it.
I had a little bit to do with getting the papers ready for the president to look at and finally approve.
But it wasn't substantive.
I didn't make a bunch of the decisions that went into it.
Of course, in the White House at this time was Admiral Light.
You must have met him.
Yeah.
Can you describe that man?
Could you describe him?
I've read his memoirs and read his personal papers and I'd just like to have someone who knew him talk about him.
Well, I don't know him that well.
I thought he was a wonderful gentleman, as far as I was concerned, and a damn good naval officer.

He could see both sides of the picture and did and he weren't automatically no damn good if you had something besides a Navy uniform on, which was not the case with some others of them I could mention.
So, I just thought he was a fine man, a fine officer and I really don't have a
a good evaluation of his capability that I don't have a firm opinion about.
I liked him very much, but that was about all I knew about him.
Another man of course is Harry Truman.

You've met the President and I knew that I've talked to a number of diplomats who are at the State Department or on duty during the Truman period and by the State Department it seems to me unanimously thought he was an excellent President because he gave so much
Well, because of the Truman Doctrine, the Marshall Plan, and because he gave the department itself so much responsibility.
How did the Air Force feel?
The Air Force felt that he was a very good person, too.
I think any president would have had a hard time untangling all of the goddamn problems that were presented to him by defense at that time, by the three services, I should say.
And what most presidents would feel like, I suspect, is grabbing them all free by the scuff of the neck and kicking the seat of their britches and telling them to go take care of their own marble.

I think the Air Force had a very great deal of respect for his views and I think he treated them well and he did make the decision that was critical to him that related to that Beat 36 controversy and more importantly to the primacy and the intercontinental ballistic missile area.
they thought a great deal of.
My contact with him was on atomic matter rather than than military matter.
And I thought he was wonderful because he could make decisions and he'd make them stick.
And it didn't make too goddamn much difference to him apparently whether Joe Blow
really thought it was a great deal or not.
He thought it was the way it ought to be, why he'd do it.
And that's what you needed.
God, I'd rather see a wrong decision than no damn decision.
So I thought he was a quite great president in terms of
not only the substance of the policies that he put out, but by the manner of getting there and the manner of implementing it.
I think it was too bad that he was shoved so quickly into the Potsdam situation, because I think with a bit of time and education, he could have probably done a better job than he did there.
Boy, I sure can't blame him for it, but he just didn't have a chance.
He was new to this scene.
And he did have some hangers around like Averell Harriman and a few others that I wouldn't want to depend on their advice, but he didn't have any other, any other place to go for it.
And why do you say that about Harriman?
I just don't, I just don't buy his approach, that's all.
I think he saw the Russians as they were so different than I see them.
He saw them as someone we would live with and get along all right with.
I don't see that.
OK. Now, as far as being in Washington as the air planner, I've talked to your office with the Joint Chiefs of Staff was either at the old State Department building or in the Pentagon.
Is that not right?
Yes.
Both.
Both.
Now, I've talked to a number of officers
Many of them were at the Pentagon from major to brigadier general and somewhere in there.
And they've always said that working in Washington, the schedules are just absolutely incredible.
A lot of long hours and seven days a week.
Is that what you found?
Could you describe your daily routine for me?
Yes, on the joint staff.
There was always, of course, a lot more work than could be accomplished.
And we did the best we could.
But if there was some problem with some urgency, you stayed there until you got it out.
And I have been in boat building, in the Pentagon in particular, for 72 hours at a time, many times.
until we could get out a war plan or get out a plan to meet some other problem that the Joint Chiefs had referred to us.
And you just work until you get it done.
Doesn't make a damn whether it's five o'clock or midnight.
That's the same thing I heard.
And the Joint Staff is not the only place that happens.
It happens in lots of places around here.
In the Atomic Energy Commission, my hours were mighty long.
Usually in the office by 7 and I'll sort them ever out by 10.
Sometimes a damn cent later than that.
I said, it's a killer.
After 20 years, you've got
enough of it.
That got me against Dubai a bit.
Now I was wondering about another thing.
Did you say before that you had been court-martialed or almost court-martialed twice?
Or are you kidding me?
Yes.
It's stretching the point a little bit as an individual to say that in connection with the Air Force trying to get loose.
All of us were on a mission out of Hamilton Field and went out to sea to intercept a Navy ship that was coming in from the Philippines.
When was this?
In 37.
At that time, the Air Force was confined to the three-mile limit, mission-wise.
We felt we had to break out of that.
If the Navy could keep us confined to the three-mile limit, it dictated the kind of airplanes we needed, everything.
And people didn't think we could go out.
a side of land because we'd get lost or some damn thing.
And we wanted to show that we could and that we could do something when we got out there.
So we vetted out and went out, I think it was six hundred miles, quite a way, over the ocean in a land airplane and dropped a slick, a bucket of aluminum powder
got near this thing and bombed it and turned around and came back home.
The Secretary of War knew all about this by the time we got home.
And the commander of that flight was already ordered to Washington before he landed.
And it looked like the whole damn bunch of us were going to be court-martialed.
It got taken care of in a rational way, so it's not quite fair to say it almost got court-martialed.
The idea was the same, because it was a court-martialable offense to fly past the three-mile limit, you see.
This is what it all boils back down to in terms of emissions.
And that just had to be changed.
So that was the first of four or five attempts before we got it changed.
And it really never got formally changed.
It just people shut up about it, and we went on better than it was.
As the war got closer, 37, you see, is not very far from the time things were beginning to get pretty hot.
The mission off-coast, which was a follow-up on this, when we were authorized to go out and intercept the Navy ship.
and we had the worst goddamn weather you can think of.
And the Navy gave us the wrong information on the ship, unless that really kind of famous one where LeMay was the navigator.
And he took the outfit out and found a damn thing anyhow and bombed it.
After that, I don't know, people just kind of shut up and got busy and got on and we built the airplanes to do what we thought they ought to do.
The story of LeMay is written up in many places and damps out more accurately than I could tell it.
I wasn't there anyhow.
I was wondering about that other time that you were almost court-martialed, too.
When was that?
Well, that doesn't have anything to do with the Air Force.
Oh, it has to do with the?
The State Department.
Oh, are you going to tell me that one?
I was, when I left Panama I went to Central America as an assistant military attache for air to Central America and Columbia.
And after a year about in Central America and San Jose, my area was divided into three
districts, three, two more attachs, and I moved to Columbia, to Bogota.
And Spurl Braden was the ambassador, American ambassador down there.
Things were getting pretty warm because that was in
December 40 or January 41, I don't remember now which, but right at the beginning of 41.
There were a lot of things to do.
The Germans were still flying SCATTA down there.
We were pressing Pan American to make necessary deals to take over SCATTA, and pressuring the Colombian government to
to do it, and they finally did, but the damn woods were full of Germans down there, so everybody was worried about the Panama Canal and that.
So I was pretty damn busy, and flying a lot of places.
I flew one mission out of there at 2300 miles in an airplane that would only fly about 750.
Oh yeah, we talked about that.
But it was a, I'd take people from the office with me on my flights as photographers and other things.
Most of them were men, one of them was a woman.
And the ambassador decided there was something wrong with that.
I never even figured out what he decided was wrong.
But I was gone until I came to Washington.
And when I got here, I found that he had preferred charges against me for carrying an unauthorized passenger.
And since they were formal charges, it wasn't something he could just walk away from.
And so I had to cancel my return to Columbia and stay in Washington and work like hell to get the thing handled.
And I finally took an appointment with the Secretary of State, the gentleman from Tennessee, to get him taken care of.
Cordell Hall.
Yeah.
My immediate boss, the military attache, Colonel Pate, was an old friend of his from Tennessee.
And so when he saw my plight, we went to see Hall because Spurl Braden worked for him.
We talked a few minutes, told him what the problem was.
He looked out the window and said to my boss, Ben, have you been devoting the proper time to meditation recently?
Colonel Pate said, yes, I think I have.
And he said, well, you see you do that.
Every man needs that.
And we left.
And I didn't hear more about it.
He apparently was, that was my only contact with him, but he apparently was a wonderful man.
How'd you get, how'd you shift into the atomic energy business?
Well.
Your next job starts to deal with that as military liaison committee, as a director of that committee to the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.
Why'd they shift you into that?
The Air Force, of course, was kind of fighting for its life in the atomic side of the picture at that time, and all the other services were too.
And the commission had just been born, actually it was two years old, and
And it went back a little further.
When I was here at A&M, I was in a, graduated as a chemical engineer.
And I don't know whether it was just fourth or fifth class, maybe, of chemical engineers to come out of here.
I'm not sure exactly where they were, but it was right there at the front someplace.
While I was here, while I was in senior here,
I had to have one special project.
And being the ambitious type at that time, I decided I'd make that project an explanation of Einstein's theory of relativity.
As long as nobody understood it, I don't think Einstein himself ever claimed he really did.
Well, it shouldn't be any problem for me.
Yes, that is very ambitious.
I bet your professors had some raised eyebrows about that.
Well, I noticed a number of them were on hand when I came to talk about it.
All of these particular projects had to be presented to the head of the department, Dr. C.C.
Hedges, the head of the Department of Chemistry at that time.
And as I found out, he didn't know anything about it either, but I didn't enlighten him a hell of a lot.
That's what it amounted to after an awful lot of work, and I busted my butt on it.
And not only did I not understand it, you couldn't find anything on it that would help you.
I just wasn't available, at least not in the resources around here.
But I went on and talked about it anyway.
I tried to block my way through, but I couldn't quite do that.
Now, Hedges tried not to laugh, but there was such that he just couldn't really keep from laughing.
I told myself at that time, God damn it, I will find out about it when I get to a place where I can.
And so I did, as time went by.
And when the atomic business came up, I thought it was something that I could understand.
And if I understood it properly, I'd have a hell of a lot better rationale about something that I thought was going to change civilization.
Change it maybe more radically than it has.
and something that could be a really good force if applied there.
So I wanted to be a part of that effort.
And so I got busy and learned about it.
And so as a member of the Joint Planning Group, I went to, as a representative of the Joint Chief, to the bikini test.
And quite a bit of time in the technical aspects of not only the weapon but the effects and the tests and the layout.
And of course you get immediately into the implications or force implications as soon as you get into those things.
And so I just kept, went on from there.
And when it came time to
leave the joint staff.
They asked me to go over there to the executive director of that committee, and I did.
So you were self-educated then, basically, as far as Yeah, and I lived with those guys, and I worked, and I studied the books, and I studied the history.
brought myself up to date as to where we were in the atomic business, and then tried to keep abreast of it from there, straight on forward, and to know the people who were involved in it.
Now as the military liaison, can you describe exactly what you did?
Well, the Atomic Energy Act of 1947
placed all of the responsibility for atomic affairs under the Atomic Energy Commission.
It recognized that there was a military use for this that had to be protected, but that
temperature of the country and the people at that time was, for Christ's sakes, let's control this thing outside the military.
and not ever give the military a means of using this without full control.
As a matter of fact, they wanted to go further than that and follow the Baruch plan and fix it so even the United States couldn't do it, much less its military.

They didn't know how to handle the Department of Defense, the things that have to go in there that didn't expect the Atomic Energy Commission to know exactly what kind of weapons that we want, or how did the military want it, how to determine how many of them were needed and what their characteristics would be and so forth.
Yet they didn't want to deal directly with the military on the matter.
So they formed a law provided for a committee as a liaison between defense and AEC and vice versa.
And that committee was headed by a civilian chairman appointed by the president, I think with the advice and consent of the Senate, although I'm not sure about that last.
It had a staff of people, military and civilian, who were full-time.
And then the committee of it itself consisted of two officers from each of the three services, plus the civilian chairman, plus two representatives from somewhere else.
And I've forgotten where they were.
It wasn't significant, anyway.
So we met, we the committee, met with the commission and relayed the needs and desires and whatnot of the Department of Defense to the commission as a basis for their action in the weapons business.
This sounds kind of simple, but it's not really quite that simple because, for example, one of the first things that happened was a determination of how many weapons do you need in the long run.
This is, of course, the biggest question that we're going to have.
How many weapons do you need?
Well, nobody knows, but...
